unnormalised: Someone asked me how much Indians typically donate to charity. It's a complex question, and the amount varies widely based on income, religious beliefs, and personal values. While there isn't a single, definitive answer, I can offer some insights.
normalised: Someone asked me how much Indians typically donate to charity. It's a complex question, and the amount varies widely based on income, religious beliefs, and personal values. While there isn't a single, definitive answer, I can offer some insights.

unnormalised: Generally, you'll see donations ranging from small amounts like Rs. 100 to larger sums of ₹5000 or more, especially during festivals like Diwali when many people donate to temples or give alms to the needy. A lot of the charitable giving happens informally – that beggar outside your building might be getting Rs. 20 daily from different people.
normalised: Generally, you'll see donations ranging from small amounts like rupee one hundred to larger sums of rupee five thousand or more, especially during festivals like Diwali when many people donate to temples or give alms to the needy. A lot of the charitable giving happens informally – that beggar outside your building might be getting rupee twenty daily from different people.

unnormalised: Looking at more formal giving, studies show that the average annual charitable donation in India is around 1-3% of a person's income. This number often jumps up during times of crisis. For instance, during the COVID-19 pandemic, donations soared, with many individuals and organizations donating millions, sometimes even $1 million or upwards to relief efforts. Many contributed to PM CARES fund.
normalised: Looking at more formal giving, studies show that the average annual charitable donation in India is around one to three percent of a person's income. unnormalised: It’s worth noting that there’s an increased awareness around charitable giving. With online platforms, more people are able to donate quickly and easily. You might see people casually donating Rs 500 through UPI. Some NGOs allow for recurring monthly donations of, say, ₹250. Every bit counts and helps!
